footnotes: Hebrew 'shamayim' is plural, emphasizing the totality of the created cosmos.
The 'Spirit of God' (Heb. ruach Elohim) moving over the waters prefigures the sacramental action of baptism.
The plural 'Let us make' has been understood by the Fathers as an indication of the Trinity.
Cf. St. Augustine, De Trinitate I.7
The Protoevangelium (First Gospel): the earliest prophecy of the Redeemer and His Mother.
The Vulgate reads 'ipsa conteret' (she shall crush), interpreting the woman as instrumental in the serpent's defeat through her seed, Christ.
The 'woman' is both Eve and, in the fuller sense, Mary—the New Eve who brings forth the New Adam.
St. Irenaeus, Adv. Haer. III.22.4: 'The knot of Eve's disobedience was loosed by Mary's obedience.'
The enmity between the woman and the serpent implies Mary's complete freedom from Satan's dominion—the Immaculate Conception.
